definitions.definition: the part of a building, object, or person's body that faces forward or is most often seen or used:
examples: The front of the museum is very impressive.

definitions.definition: the part of a vehicle that is nearest to its direction of movement:
examples: Do you want to sit in the front (= next to the driver)?

definitions.definition: the outside part or cover of a book, newspaper, or magazine:
examples: There was a picture of the Trevi fountain on the front of the book.

definitions.definition: one of the first pages in a book:
examples: There's an inscription in the front of the book.

definitions.definition: further forward than someone or something else:
examples: The car in front suddenly stopped and I slammed on the brakes.
By half time the Italians were well in front.

definitions.definition: close to the front part of something:
examples: There's parking space in front of the hotel.

definitions.definition: where someone can see or hear you:
examples: Please don't swear in front of the children.

definitions.definition: If you give someone an amount of money up front, you pay that person before they do something for you:
examples: He wants all the money up front or he won't do the job.

definitions.definition: in or at the front of something:
examples: One of his front teeth is missing.

definitions.definition: If a building or area fronts (onto) a particular place, it is near it and faces it:
examples: All the apartments front onto the sea.

definitions.definition: to lead an organization or group of musicians:
examples: She fronts a large IT company.

definitions.definition: If a building is fronted with something, its surface is covered with it:
examples: The kitchen has oak cabinets fronted with glass.

definitions.definition: a group of people sharing a political belief who perform actions in public to achieve their aims:
examples: The National Front is an extremely right-wing political party in Britain.
